Introduction: ^. You've been appointed captain of a scientific journey into the depths of the Earth; your mission, to find and study a Wyrm. Wyrms are dreadful beasts that thrive in the deep dark soil under the earth; you and your crew are prepared to do whatever it takes. Your reward;

s0: ^the endless gratitude of the philosopher-kings of Athens.
s5: ^a mausoleum in the Field of the Wyrmchasers

Introduction: ^. The deeper you dig, the more difficult things will get; but the closer you'll come to finding the wyrm.
Officer: ^You sit on deck, at the very top of the Wyrmdigger. Sub-Metic
^ suggests you call for an officer's report.

s: ^Get a Sound Report from the Oread
^Ask the Pedon of the crew and Digger

Oread: ^The Oread is suspended above you, strapped into

b: ^what looks like a giant, exploded golden clock

s0: ^hands massaging two foot long metal bars
s1: ^bare feet on a long, curved tube
s2: ^fingers dancing against a vibrating set of tuning forks
s3: ^one finger to her lips, another skipping on a spinning sphere

s0: ^She pauses for a beat, shocked, then roars with laughter. Worried crew turn to watch. "Sure! Sure! Go for it!" You strap in. She talks you free it and you... Feel. Feel for changes, movement, the lack of movement. A chrous of rock. A solo of water. A harmony of gas. Your feet for bass, your hands for tenor. It's not an experience for words. She grins broadly. "Nice. Come back anytime, Chief. Then we can really sing."
s1: ^"Sorry Chief, not today. Limestone interference. Another time."

c: ^She doesn't turn away from her work.

b: ^"Upper Lithosphere. Picking up a fair amount
^"Lower Lithosphere." Her eyes are clenched tight "Lot of interference down here
^Her face is gaunt. Etched with sweat. "Mantle. So low. I can't tell what's what
^." She looks bored. "Cithaeron's got nothing. Rocks. Soil. Ruins. Soil."
^..." Her ear is against a metal tube. "Something... Maybe volcanic. Unsure."
^. I hear it, though. Wyrm-noise. Faint, rhythmic, close." She puts up her hand to ward you off.
^, yet here it is. The Wyrm. We're close. So close. I can feel it. All around us."

^-" She screws her eyes up in pain, "The pain! By Zeus... here! Outside, it's-" She bites off her words and clamps her hands over her ears. The machinery is vibrating. The Wyrmdigger is vibrating. You are vibrating.

s2: ^She opens her eyes for the first time, and leans down to you. Her eyes are green, like emeralds. "Bacchae-Thebian Cithaeron Nexus. System of reverberators.  Picks up on escaping Nerve Branches. From Arterial Steam Tributaries. Stuff happens outside. They pick it up. It comes back. And. I. Listen. To. It." She punctuates each word with a fist, punching a metal bar that rings dully with each strike. "It's! Called! The! Cithaeron!" She stares at you, teeth bared.

c: ^She nods, and turns away. The humming continues, after you walk away

Aeolikos: ^The Chief Aeolikos is down in the bowels of the Wyrmdigger, close to the drill. You have to communicate by Hermetic pipe message.

s: ^You type; "How is all in engines STOP"

^half tilt, not quit 40. ok could b beter but good. to many rocks
^boiler is well moving fasterly. nerly 60. fast ish
^over 80 is good full tilt, full power that is. stoker flat out
^"VERY FAS near top speed. 100!!!! is good. prefect
^almos cold lots of water. keepin cool how u r also cool (joke)
^startin to build have used steam releses. might get warmer
^getting danggerous canot contain. very warm. hope u are ok
^high. water low. getting crit- critic- cri- bad. losing control
^have sealed boiler. vents dont work. men died. must stop. too hot. is bad. trapped. the heat is
^The piece of paper is charred all over. The capsule is red hot. The pipe itself, bent in the heat. They could be dead. The scroll slips from your sweat-slicked hands

s0: ^The tube is filthy, covered in grime. Dirty fingerprints are all over the scroll
s1: ^Enclosed in the capusle was two hefting pieces of coal. This explains the return delay
s2: ^The edges of the paper are stained. They've tried spelling 'SPEED' three or four times on this one

c: ^"have u been in a digger engines before? pleas be honest" the return message reads.
^He replies, naming 'heat' and 'bad condisions' as excuses why you couldn't possibly visit. Even through the grammatical errors, you sense this isn't the truth.
^You send down a thin volume from the Digger's library "much apprecited! will remember this. thank"
^"k" says the message. A person of many words.

Tour: ^"Gud!" says the return message. "Honesty is best policy. Is danggerous here and need that." You descend down, through the levels. The corridors get lower, the staircases turn to ladders. You squeeze through the emergency seal and step out into light and heat. A great room, larger even than the deck, and spinning at its core - The Aeolipile. Silhouetted against the blaze is the Chief Aeolikos, arms outstretched, "A pleasure to finally meet you, Metic!"

c: ^You talk of the Aeolipile, pressure controls, steam driving, the gear shaft for the driller. He is really rather erudite, and admits to having once been a Metic. "My writing impediment meant I could only go so far. Besides, this is my real passion." He beams ear to ear.

InterviewAeolikosTourIntro: ^"Gud! Honesty is best policy. Is danggerous here and need truth." You descend down, through the levels. The corridors get lower, the staircases turn to ladders.

s: ^Step out into the light and heat.

InterviewAeolikosTour: ^The Aeolipile spins on. Stokers work furiously, shirtless muscles glistening.

s0: ^Silhouetted against the blaze is the Chief Aeolikos, arms outstretched, "Metic! A pleasure!"

c: ^Your head swims. The heat, ever present, becomes too much. The Chief Aeolikos grabs your arm firmly "Easy now. Let's get back. You've done better than most. Better than I did. Come down again sometime. I appreciated it. Send me poetry. I miss poetry, down here."

^You talk of the Aeolipile, pressure controls, steam driving, the gear shaft for the driller. They are really rather erudite, even admitting to once having been a Sub-Metic themselves. "My unfortunate writing impediment meant I could only go so far. Besides, this is my real passion." They beam ear to ear.

^A ten foot sphere of spinning bronze, blowing white hot. "Quite impressive, no?" asks the Chief Aeolikos. "I built it myself. It's a hybrid - The Makedonians build great Male steam engines, the Athenians Female. This is something altogether different. Special." They grin that broad grin. "Much like you and I, eh, Metic?"

Quartermaster: ^"Welcome!" The Quartermaster is a well built, bearded gentlemen. He exhales lurid blue pipesmoke.

b: ^. Good to see you're still on your feet. Want something?"

Quartermaster: ^. His eyes are two different colours;

b: ^Didn't the Oread have something strange with her eyes too?
^His fingers drum the desk. "We're comfortable enough, considering.
^One finger taps the desk. "I'm getting warm, I must say. Nothing unbearable, though.
^He crossed his arms. "Something needs to be done about this heat.
^He fans himself with his pipe. "This heat is getting too much, I must say.
^His face is glistening. His eyes are just a bit wild. "Hot, Metis. Very hot.

^" He looks desperately at you. His office is strewn with empty drinking vessels of various kinds. "We have to get out of here. I've seen this sort of thing before. One more day, that's all it'll take. One more day. After that..." he trails off, and stares glumly at the floor. Outside, a crewman recites something about the joy of dirt.
^" He grimaces. "Things are looking pretty ugly, in all honesty. If we don't do something soon... well. I won't worry you."

s0: ^Haven't had a good birthday party in a while, I think.
s1: ^Fresh food's are running low. Plenty of cans to go round, mind.
s2: ^Some of them were expecting more excitement.

b: ^" He takes a swig from his
^. "Crew could be more enthusiastic, but I don't mind. Tried throwing a party? That usually cheers them up."
^. "Crew's getting on as well as I could ask for, though. If that's not cause for celebration, what is?"

c: ^He takes a long drag as you leave.
^The Quartermaster grins, before diving back into a ledger.

s15: ^and yet unlike anything you've ever had before

s5: ^the kind of water a princess might drink

s0: ^The Pedon is not what you expect. You imagined a similarly minded Metic, a tall, older gentleman of great beard and wisdom. Instead the Metic is

Pedon: ^impossibly youthful, boiling over with frenetic energy. The lad steps up with a quick, slightly askew salute.

b: ^"I've gathered what men we have left!" His hand trembles "One last push!
^"That last sortie was..." His face contorts "The crew took it bad. We'll pull through!
^"We're down a crewperson or two!" He fidgets, "Poor
^"Still in fine spirits! Nothing we've not handle before, I guess!
^"Doing good! That is, the crew are, Metic! All in one piece!
^Easy driving, though! Piloting, that is, or Pedoning, I guess. Or... Anyway, not that deep, yet!"
^She's straining, Metic, but there's much more in her! Barely into hard rock yet!"
^The Wyrmdigger is grand. In her element! Nothing can stop her!"
^But we are so, so deep. I've never been..." He trails off, looking away.

^"Our depth is... Is..." He locks eyes with you. There is a fire in there. A glint of something wild and wondrous and wrong. "Deep. So deep. Deeper than anyone has ever gone." He smiles, a huge, wild grin showing many, many teeth.

c: ^You grab the Pedon just before turning in for the night.

b: ^He's a little shy at first, but opens up with a drink or two. He's very interested in dreams, for some reason. "Have you had any? Any dreams about Wyrms?" You're more interested in his understanding of Wyrm biology, which seems solid, but the topic bores him.
^You come rushing back. He grins that broad, broad grin. "We're all having them now." he says, "All of us, and more every day. I think
^ that we couldn't wake up? He's got something to do with it." You feel a creeping sensation. Fear?
^The Pedon is smiling even wider as you rush to him with a stack of your own dream notes. "The food!" he says. "It's the food!

^ wasn't eating and his dreams, well, they stopped! Mystery solved! Panic over! Science prevails!" This does not help. You ask him if he's concerned; "Nonsense! All will be well! All will be well!" and with that he pushes you from the door. Perhaps the Pedon is more Metic than you, after all...
^He laughs - "All will be well and all manner of things will be well. Once you know a thing, you cannot fear it. Fear is the mind killer, dontcha know!"

c: ^The Pedon nods furiously. "I have notes to compile..."

Mutiny: ^Your crew are tired of being cooped up in this metal coffin. "

s5: ^We want to see my family again!
s10: ^I don't even like wyrms that much!

Mutiny: ^" they shout. A mutiny is brewing.

Diplomacy: ^Diplomacy never hurt anyone; but it takes time, time, precious time, while all the while the heat of the earth seeps into your wyrmdigger.

c: ^If we turn back now, what was the point of all this? Some of your crew mumble in agreement; but that argument isn't likely to work twice.
^The atmosphere is nervous; no one person is entirely sure of their neighbour's convictions. In the end, the tie is broken by a single vote; yours.

Diplomacy: ^Struggle, one last time, to persuade them.

c: ^You beg, you bargain, you plead; you're so close, now, so close! Giving up now would be folly! Eventually, after what feels like years of protest, you manage to bring them around; but this is your last chance. You'll never manage it again.

^ No matter how hard you try, it's impossible to put forward a reasonable argument. Any longer in this cradle of horrors and there'll be nothing left of you. You are swiftly deposed, and your crew start the long journey back to the surface.

Rebellion: ^Brutal, short and to the point; violence is the answer to many questions.

c: ^Drawing your ceremonial sword, you make an example of the most racuous mutineer. The message is clear; the mutiny dies down, but your crew's loyalty is frayed.

s: ^If it's war they want... Then it's a war they'll get. You gather your loyalists and bunker down. When the fighting stops, you're left standing; unfortunately, most of your crew isn't.

c: ^Holing up in the captain's office, you fight and fight and fight. A few loyal souls remain to you, 'til the bitter end; when the mutiny has been broken, they're even fewer. You sustained a hefty wound in the fight; it's not lethal, but if things turn sour again, you won't be in any condition to protect yourself.
^ It's no good; your crew's loyalty is frayed, and you won't last a second in a fight. Give up, return to the surface.

s1: ^It's considered lucky to have two birthdays in one voyage.
s8: ^The crew are definitely trying to pull something here.

s0: ^the next morning, you find that somebody drunkenly nudged you off course. You've spent the past few hours heading away from the worm!
s1: ^somebody got a bit too rowdy and damaged some of the hull.
s2: ^when the hangover hits, they won't be.
s4: ^everybody was too busy partying to check on the drill, and you've dug deeper than you expected

c: ^ and all their friends are very sad.

Drill_1: ^Your drill churns ever onward, through miles of dirt and stone. You have a quiet evening to yourself.

s0: ^You stretch, yawn, and lean back in your chair.
s1: ^You flip through a book on philosophy
s2: ^You read the hot new epic that's all the rage lately
s5: ^It's nice to take some time off every now and then.
s6: ^You enjoy exactly one jug of wine.
s7: ^You chat briefly with some of your crew, but they don't have anything interesting to say.
s8: ^You fiddle about with the latest steam-curiosity.
s9: ^A fun time was had by all.
s11: ^You read an exciting poem about a wyrmchaser. It's hardly accurate, but it is thrilling.

c: ^They tell you that they could increase the speed, but it'll take its toll on the hull.

s7: ^Looking out the window is always wildly exciting.

Drill_2: ^Your drill is a great corkscrew sheathed in steel, spiraling ever downwards. Every now and then, it digs up trouble; but not today.
Drill_3: ^On the surface, they think the only thing to be found this deep is horror and death. Not so; occasionally, you find boredom.
Drill_4: ^The efforts of Athens' finest minds have gotten you this far, but even they must find themselves at a loose end sometimes.

s2: ^far too early for this sort of thing

s0: ^I can't sleep, see, with all the noise, so I've been thinking...
s1: ^Cap, us and the boys have been talking

b: ^Reckon the hull can't take much more of this heat. We need to find a way to cool it, and fast.
^What are we going to do when we find this wyrm?

c: ^"All shall be well, and maybe all manner of thing too!"
^Must you do everything on this damn digger!? You're the captain here, and you're doing fine; that's what matters.

s0: ^ slinks away. The next time you see them, they're working with renewed vigour.
s1: ^All nods and humble mutterings, but the
^ isn't one to forget this kind of thing.

s0: ^There's an Officer for this kind of thing; usually is, anyway.
s1: ^The worry stays etched on their face as they rush back out.

Dozing_off: ^The constant whir of the drill feels almost restful. Nobody will mind if you just lie here for a moment...

c: ^Just close your eyes for a bit, it'll be fine.

s2: ^ You pass through the soil like a fish in water.
s3: ^ The tracks you leave behind are a testament to your majesty.

s1: ^ A twisting maze of many tunnels, all unalike.

s2: ^ Spiraling inwards, towards a definite point, eternally.
s3: ^ The wide becomes thin, becomes wide again.
s4: ^ Pierce the vault of the earth.
s5: ^Your body is a stair; your head, a spear.

c: ^You sit upright; can't sleep, you have work to do!

Ration_trouble: ^Your crew are concerned that they're going to starve before they ever catch sight of a wyrm.

c: ^Can't do much about it this far underground.

tracks: ^Your scouts have reported something at the fringes of the drill-lights; something like a wyrmtrack. Not the track you're following... probably.

c: ^Maybe it'll be something interesting; maybe you'd been drifting off course the whole time.
^You remain resolutely stuck to your current path.

s4: ^The rasp of metal. Not the hull?

weird_creaking: ^. The crews eyes swivel as they finger weapons.
tremor: ^ Whatever the case, your wyrmdigger isn't in good shape.
lost_trail: ^You've lost sight of the wyrmtrack somewhere in all the dirt and darkness.

c: ^If you keep going down, you'll find it eventually.

gasdanger: ^Chief Aeoliphile warns you that you're running straight into a pocket of gas.

s0: ^You emerge unscathed on the other side. That was practically a shortcut; you've gained on the wyrm.
s1: ^Everything explodes! You survive but only just about. The crew are almost as badly shaken as the engines.
^Fans just move the stifling air around in circles

s0: ^A day's diversion finds an underground river; You refill the onboard Baths, but the wyrm has pressed on without you...
s1: ^A day of pointless drilling; You find nothing. The heat feels so much worse for that wasted effort

s0: ^The crew strip down to undergarments, and you join them. Hellenic spirit prevails!
s1: ^The crew clench their teeth and crack on, working tirelessly. The heat lingers.

Diamonds: ^'s eyes shine just as brightly in the lamplight. These aren't what you've come here for; but few among the crew can prevent their naked greed from showing.

c: ^A bonus even your crew can't complain at! Except for the Stoker, whose engines now groan under the extra weight...
^Mutinous stares and grim faces, but you know the real prize awaits in the depths.

Wyrmcast: ^The wyrm has passed through here, shedding its skin as it passed. A slimy, sinuous cast of wyrmflesh lies in the way of your drill.
^Use the beak-shards to sharpen the drill

c: ^The wyrm once used this beak to cut through the earth; now you'll do it in its stead. Wyrmdiggers are not so unlike the wyrms themselves.

s1: ^The hull wasn't built for the added friction, though.

Wyrmcast: ^Use the moult to harden the hull

c: ^Its segmented flesh is harder than boiled leather, perfectly adapted to the stresses of the deep earth.

s1: ^The extra weight's slowing you down, mind.

c: ^They pay well for this meat in Athens; your crew should consider themselves fortunate. Indeed, there's a giddy atmosphere in the air as the first wyrm-rations are served...

s1: ^Perhaps too giddy; the next day, you find that the drill has somehow inverted itself.

Shroom: ^Use the stems to patch up your hull

c: ^Not the most solid material on or under the earth, but it'll hold things together for a while
^Mushroom-flesh is woody and unappetising, but it provides enough sustenance for now. Your crew aren't wildly enthusiastic about them, but food is food.

Encampment: ^Some explorers have set up shop here; they have tools and supplies you could use.

s0: ^They only have old cans and some unappetising mushrooms, but it'll keep you going.
s2: ^They're pleased with what you've brought; you get a little more than you bargained for
s3: ^You can't really afford their prices; one of the crew looks forlornly at a

s1: ^nothing more than a few cans and bits of string
s3: ^some wood which seems sturdy, but falls to bits after a few moments of drilling

WyrmGlimpse: ^Shouting from the observation deck! There've been sightings of something pale and undulating, just beyond the drill's tip. Could it be the

c: ^This is it! This is what you've been looking for! You whip the stokers up into a frenzy (not literally, of course), and the wyrmdigger lurches forward, scraping along the tunnel walls.
^You've come this far; no need to throw it all away at the final hurdle. Slowly, steadily, your drill weaves its way into the wyrm's tunnel.

Glimpse2: ^Your drill cracks through the levee of the wyrm's tunnel. Piercing the layer of the wyrm's tunnel takes time; slowly, slowly, slowly but surely, you ease your way into the great beast's tunnel.

c: ^You have your notepad ready. Steel yourself.

Toolate: ^The drill pierces the thick levee of soil the wyrm disturbed. But too slow, too little, too late! You arrive only in time to see the wyrm insinuating itself further and further into the earth. But you have it now; wyrms find the vibrations of the drill impossibly enticing. It'll dance around you like a moth around a flame; and when it comes, you'll be ready.

WyrmRunin: ^!", the shout comes up. The wyrm has pierced your tunnel; this is the best chance you're going to have to get up close and personal. But what will you do with the wyrm when you reach it?
^Complete your mission: Study the wyrm for science

c: ^ You've been given a task, and you intend to complete it; even if it seems mundane.
^ Killing a wyrm has a glory of its very own. Turn your wyrmdigger to face the beast head-on.

WyrmChaseScience: ^Hand your notebook to a scribe; it'll be easier if you can dedicate all your focus to

c: ^ Head-on accounts of wyrms like this are rare. You manage to bark out half a description of
^, but it sweeps upon you with terrible speed! This is the best view of a wyrm you're ever going to get!
^ The wyrm is right there! It's time to flee, before there's nothing left of you.

WyrmChaseMurder: ^Charge! Your drill takes time to align, but the wyrm's still some distance away. You ready a battlecry: "
^". It's not very good, but you're only a scientist. The wyrm's great maw descends upon you, and everything turns black.

c: ^ Face a Wyrm in single combat? You? You're a scientist, not a warrior!

ScienceEnding: ^The inside of a Wyrm! Nobody has ever been inside a wyrm and survived before! This is, as it turns out, for good reason. Your drill is crushed and crumpled to nothing by the wyrm's great digestion. On the bright side, if anyone ever manages to find your mangled wyrmdigger, they'll find the most comprehensive account of a wyrm's bowels on or under the earth.
MurderEnding: ^Cackling maniacally, your driller rockets towards the

^, powered by Alexandria's finest engines. Few wyrmchasers have ever fought a wyrm and survived; for good reason, as it turns out. The inside of a wyrm is terribly hostile towards anything that isn't a wyrm, and your wyrmdriller certainly wasn't built for it. A swarm of tiny parasitic
^'s lunge for your driller, burrowing into every crack and crevice of your ship. You hear

^ scream; then you, too, are beset by wyrms. Somehow, your foolish endeavour actually ended well. Your driller managed to stumble forward and pierce the wyrm's tiny brain, ending its life instantly. Some day, someone may find the husk of the wyrm; and your drill, crewed by skeletons.
LoserEnding: ^Your nerve doesn't hold; you flee from the wyrm before it falls upon you with all its slithering might. The surface is far, far, far away, and your crew is scattered or dazed or half-dead. Eventually, your drill shudders to a halt; the sane and stable among you, few though you are, manage to crawl through a tunnel into a fungal cavern. You live out the rest of your days there, and never see the sun again. It's not a good life; you wonder what you might have gained, if you had managed to steel yourself just a moment longer.
HeatFailure: ^Fires are starting to break out across the wyrmdigger. Your crew are collapsing like sandcastles in wind. You're standing in a puddle of sweat larger than some oceans. Unless you do something soon, that puddle will be all that's left of you.

c: ^If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. If you can't stand the ever-present crushing warmth of the depths of the earth, get out of the warm bits of the depths of the earth. With the Oread's help, you can find a reprieve; you just need to find it hidden in the vibrations. Carefully, cautiously, listening with the care of an inexperienced cat-burglar, you guide the driller towards your salvation. A lake! Hidden underground, a pocket of water, exactly what you need to cool off a burning piece of machinery. The drill isn't designed for underwater transit, of course, so you can't do much but wait uncomfortably for the water to drain off. It's saved you for now; but if things get worse again, there'll be no hope. No other lakes to be had.

HeatEnding: ^Despite the desperate, panicked efforts of your crew and officers, there's nothing you can do to prevent your drill, your shell, the barrier between you and the endless depths of the earth, from coming to pieces. Without a drill you are nothing more than tiny, tiny specks, in a land which is not your own, helplessly wandering to their end.
DepthFailure: ^Too deep! Your whole hull starts creaking and moaning, like crushed aluminium. Which it will be fairly soon, if you stay this far underground; the pull of the Underworld is strong here, and no wyrmdigger could be built for such an awesome force.
^But they are built for something else.

c: ^It's true; not even the arts and minds in the hearts of Athens could manage to build anything that could survive a situation like this. However, you've gathered that they probably could build something to escape a situation like this. You dash belowdecks with all the speed you can muster, crack open the emergency seal, and behold the majesty of the control panel. The Corinthians build these systems, and only they truly can understand them. But you've picked up enough from your time belowdecks to pull off something fairly remarkable. You twist dials, pull levers, and adjust the orrery-wheels to the Aeolus Configuration. In short; you tell the hidiously complex machinery to vent a massive quantity of steam from the front of the drill. Steam has to work hard to lift an entire wyrmdigger; but it does work, and shunts you a good distance up the tunnel, to a point where the drill no longer screams quite so urgently. You're not going to be able to do this again; it takes far too much steam to do it twice. But it's bought you time.

DepthEnding: ^The drill continues its descent into a land it was never built for. The Aeolikos, the Oread, the Pedon; none of their efforts can extricate you from this situation. Your drill cuts open a vein of the earth, spilling the hot red blood of the depths, consuming you and your crew in a great crushing flagration. The heat finds you before the rock does.
CrewFailure: ^No mutiny, this. The stresses and strains of the uttermost depths have taken their toll on your crew's wellbeing; and on your own. The few among you that remain are in desperate danger of succumbing to madness. You can hear one of your crew screaming that they're a drill, while desperately trying to corkscrew through a wall. Things are looking grim. You feel like twisting into the earth yourself.

c: ^Standing on a nearby crate, you bellow at your crew: "What is the best in life?", you roar, shaking the earth, mightier than the most colossal wyrm. Their responses are as varied as they are muted; wearied laughter, unintelligible moans, strange mantras about the taste and texture of soft black earth, weeping, silence. That's okay; that's what you expected. Nodding, as if they'd provided you with some valuable input, you wheel out your last-ditch gamble; a table piled high with the finest delicacies. Well, as fine as you can muster in a steel box miles under the earth. The sights, colours, smells, tastes; these things help revive your crew, giving them something-like-focus. Press on, while you still can.

CrewEnding: ^Fall to the floor. You shall not rise again. You are nothing but a slug, a snake, a snail, legless and limbless, crawling on the earth, on the belly of a beast. What else could you be, so far under the ground? This land was not made for the mind, therefore, no mind can exist within this land. Lie still. Lie still.
